body:
In Japanese cooking, a makisu () is a small mat woven from bamboo and cotton string that is used in food preparation. Makisu are most commonly used to make a kind of rolled sushi called makizushi (), commonly called maki. They are also used to shape other soft foods such as omelets, and to squeeze excess liquid out of food.
A makisu is usually 25 cm  25 cm, although they come in various sizes. Generally, there are two variations, one with thin flat bamboo strips and the other with small cylindrical strips (see attached photo). Some cooks cover the makisu with plastic film before use to reduce the cleaning effort. This is especially necessary for producing uramaki (), a kind of maki with the rice on the outside of the roll. After use, a makisu should be scrubbed to remove food particles and thoroughly air dried to avoid the growth of bacteria and fungi. Makisu are inexpensive so people can simply dispose of them after use.  
Makisu is called  (Kimbal) or  (Kimbap Mali) in Korea and is used to roll  (kimbap).


== References ==
summary: The primary use of a makisu in food preparation is to create rolled sushi, known as makizushi or maki. This involves placing ingredients on the mat, rolling them together with the help of the makisu, and then slicing them into bite-sized pieces. Beyond sushi, a makisu can also be utilized to shape other soft foods, such as omelets, allowing cooks to form these ingredients into compact shapes. Additionally, it is helpful for squeezing excess liquid out of various foods, ensuring that they maintain the right texture and moisture level for cooking. Some chefs also use a makisu covered with plastic film to simplify the cleaning process, particularly when preparing uramaki, which is a type of sushi with rice on the outside.

body:
Warrenton is an unincorporated community in northeastern Fayette County, Texas, United States. Located on State Highway 237 between Spencer Pool and Coon Creek, twelve miles northeast of La Grange.  Founded by William Neese, who landed in Galveston in 1847 and named the new settlement that grew around his store for Warren Ligon, another early colonist. This area was settled by many German colonists who, with an admixture of Anglos, formed several small farming communities based on the production of cotton, corn, and dairy products. The community flourished in the late 1800s. A post office was established in 1873, when the town had a population of over 100, churches, schools, a gin, and supporting businesses. Poor soil conditions led to a shift to cattle and poultry after 1900. By 1950, the number of businesses in Warrenton had declined to seven, and the population held at 180. By 1985, the population was down to fifty, but twelve antique stores had opened and St. Martin's Church, at twelve by sixteen feet proclaimed the world's smallest Catholic church, attract visitors. The population reached sixty-five in 2000.
Warrenton hosts Trade Days on the second weekend of the month. It is also part of the Round Top Antiques Fair in the spring and fall. This is a very large antique show in several rural communities near Round Top and Warrington between Austin and Houston. The show is generally held the at end of September and beginning of October, then again in late March and early of April. Held across several weekends, it brings in approximately 100,000 visitors from across the nation and about 600 vendors.
The Sterling McCall Old Car Museum was one of the local attractions.  On display in this museum were over 130 vehicles from the prized collection of Mr. Sterling B. McCall Jr., ranging in vintage from 1908 to 1967. The collection was begun in 1979.  The museum facility was completed in 1998, enlarged in 1999, and again in 2003.  In March 2013, the buildings were re-purposed as an antique showcase & event center. Today, the buildings house 'The Lone Star Glamp Inn', an indoor "trailer park" experience furnished with remodeled vintage trailers and themed teepees.
summary: During the late 1800s, Warrenton experienced economic growth, supported by a post office established in 1873 and a vibrant community including over 100 residents, churches, schools, and various businesses. The economy primarily thrived on the production of cotton, corn, and dairy products. However, as the soil conditions deteriorated, the community faced challenges that diminished agricultural productivity. After 1900, this led to a significant transition in the local economy, with residents shifting focus towards cattle and poultry farming instead of crop production. By 1950, the number of businesses in Warrenton had declined to just seven, demonstrating the economic difficulties faced, while the population stabilized at around 180.

These industries brought in new job opportunities and contributed to the town's continued growth and prosperity.

The town's rich agricultural history and its diverse economic development have shaped Warrenton's landscape and culture to this day.

body: The Embassy of Indonesia, Stockholm (Indonesian: Kedutaan Besar Republik Indonesia di Stockholm; Swedish: Indonesiens ambassad i Stockholm) is the diplomatic mission of the Republic of Indonesia to the Kingdom of Sweden. The embassy is also accredited to the Republic of Latvia. The current ambassador is Kamapradipta Isnomo who was appointed by President Joko Widodo in September 2020.
summary: The Embassy of Indonesia in Stockholm holds a significant role as it is not only the diplomatic mission to Sweden but is also accredited to the Republic of Latvia. This dual accreditation allows Indonesia to manage and nurture its diplomatic, economic, and cultural relations with both countries from a single location, which can lead to more efficient communication and cooperation in various areas, including trade, investment, and cultural exchange. By being accredited to Latvia, the embassy can engage in bilateral discussions, participate in joint initiatives, and address issues pertinent to both nations simultaneously. This arrangement reflects Indonesia's commitment to expanding its diplomatic footprint in Northern Europe and fostering a broader regional engagement, thereby enhancing Indonesia's influence and promoting its national interests in the region more effectively.

Overall, the Embassy of Indonesia in Stockholm serves as a valuable link between Indonesia and Sweden, and the dual accreditation could potentially improve diplomatic relations between the two countries.

body: Bely Rast High Voltage Research Station (Russian:  ) is a facility for the development of high voltage equipment in Russia, situated at Bely Rast, Moscow Oblast near the eponymous station of the Greater Ring of the Moscow Railway.  Built in 1966, the equipment of the 750 kV- and 1150 kV-lines in Russia and other parts of the former Soviet Union were first developed and tested at this facility, as well as the equipment for the never completed HVDC EkibastuzCentre. The facility also has an unused 1150 kV AC and a 1500 kV DC line. The DC line was the prototype of the never finished HVDC EkibastuzCentre.
summary: The development of high voltage equipment.

body:
Fort Baker is one of the components of California's Golden Gate National Recreation Area. The Fort, which borders the City of Sausalito in Marin County and is connected to San Francisco by the Golden Gate Bridge, served as an Army post until the mid-1990s, when the headquarters of the 91st Division moved to Parks Reserve Forces Training Area.  It is located opposite Fort Point at the entrance to the San Francisco Bay.
Fort Baker was previously named the Lime Point Military Reservation.  It was renamed in 1897.
Fort Baker is named for Edward Dickinson Baker, a former U.S. Senator from Oregon. Active in California politics in the 1850s, Baker lost his life while leading a regiment of Union troops in the Civil War. He and his wife are buried in the San Francisco National Cemetery at the Presidio.
Fort Baker was included in a historic district listing on the National Register of Historic Places in 1973, as part of 
Forts Baker, Barry, and Cronkhite.
Fort Baker features essentially intact historic structures and landscapes, and is currently under the jurisdiction of the National Park Service (NPS). It is known for its views of the San Francisco Bay.
summary: Edward Dickinson Baker; he lost his life while leading Union troops in the Civil War.

Mordella cata is a species of beetle in the genus Mordella of the family Mordellidae, which is part of the superfamily Tenebrionoidea. It was discovered in 1891.


== References ==
summary: The year 1891 is significant as it marks the discovery of the species Mordella cata. This discovery contributes to the understanding of beetle diversity within the family Mordellidae, which is itself a segment of the expansive superfamily Tenebrionoidea. The identification of Mordella cata not only adds to the catalog of known beetle species but also reflects ongoing taxonomic research, which aids in evolutionary studies and biodiversity assessments. The classification of this species alongside others in a shared family emphasizes the importance of morphological and genetic relationships in biology, showcasing how researchers can trace lineage and ecological relationships through careful classification.

Lecithocera megalopis is a moth in the family Lecithoceridae. It is found in Taiwan, China (Jiangxi) and the Philippines.
The wingspan is 1617 mm. The forewings are pale ochreous-yellowish or whitish-ochreous, more or less sprinkled with fuscous. The discal stigmata are large and black, the second connected with the tornus by a rather dark fuscous shade. There is a marginal series of small dark fuscous dots around the apex and termen. The hindwings are light grey.


== References ==
summary: Large black discal stigmata, a second stigma connected to the tornus by a dark fuscous shade, and a marginal series of small dark fuscous dots.

body: The Volunteer Force was a citizen army of part-time rifle, artillery and engineer corps, created as a popular movement throughout the British Empire in 1859. Originally highly autonomous, the units of volunteers became increasingly integrated with the British Army after the Childers Reforms in 1881, before forming part of the Territorial Force in 1908. Most of the regiments of the present Army Reserves  Infantry, Artillery, Engineers and Signals units are directly descended from Volunteer Force units.
summary: The Childers Reforms

body: The Volunteer Force was a citizen army of part-time rifle, artillery and engineer corps, created as a popular movement throughout the British Empire in 1859. Originally highly autonomous, the units of volunteers became increasingly integrated with the British Army after the Childers Reforms in 1881, before forming part of the Territorial Force in 1908. Most of the regiments of the present Army Reserves  Infantry, Artillery, Engineers and Signals units are directly descended from Volunteer Force units.
summary: 1881 reforms of the Volunteer Force included the establishment of the 'Permanent Army' and the abolition of the 'Reserve Force'.

body: Abkhazia (Abkhaz:  Apsny, Georgian:  Apkhazeti or Abkhazeti, Russian:  Abkhazia) is a de facto independent, partially recognised country lying on the eastern coast of the Black Sea, its southern border. body: Elin Hilderbrand (born July 17, 1969) is an American writer, mostly of romance novels. Her novels are typically set on and around Nantucket, where she resides. In 2019, New York magazine called her "the queen of beach reads".
summary: Elin Hilderbrand's novels are typically set on and around Nantucket, an island off the coast of Massachusetts. This picturesque setting provides a backdrop of natural beauty and a unique atmosphere that enhances the romantic elements of her stories. Nantucket's charm, culture, and coastal lifestyle serve not only as a physical setting but also as a character itself, influencing the narratives and the experiences of her characters. The setting reflects a sense of escapism, which resonates well with readers looking for the classic beach read experience.

body: The Tour de Grisset (Grisset Tower) is the remains of a small, Gallo-Roman temple or fanum located in Frteval, Loir-et-Cher, France. It is one of the few Gallo-Roman fana to still be standing, and perhaps the only one with its brick vault still in place. Excavations in the 1960s revealed a bath complex and series of other structures at the site, and it has been proposed that a small, secondary agglomeration of structures (possibly additional fana) may also exist there.
summary: Its brick vault.

body: The Tour de Grisset (Grisset Tower) is the remains of a small, Gallo-Roman temple or fanum located in Frteval, Loir-et-Cher, France. It is one of the few Gallo-Roman fana to still be standing, and perhaps the only one with its brick vault still in place. Excavations in the 1960s revealed a bath complex and series of other structures at the site, and it has been proposed that a small, secondary agglomeration of structures (possibly additional fana) may also exist there.
summary: The Tour de Grisset is still largely intact, with the exception of the upper levels which were destroyed during the French Revolution. The remaining structure still stands tall and is a significant architectural feature of the city.

Griphognathus (from Greek:  grfos 'riddle') and Greek:  gnthos 'jaw') is an extinct genus of lungfish from the late Devonian period of Europe and Australia.
Griphognathus was a specialized lungfish, about 60 centimetres (24 in) long, with an elongated snout. The lower jaw and palate were lined with tooth-like denticles. Like all other lungfish, its skin was covered by overlapping scales, and it had an asymmetrical tail.
summary: Late Devonian period of Europe and Australia.

John Mordaunt, 2nd Baron Mordaunt (15081571) was an English baron and member of the House of Lords. He had previously represented Bedfordshire in the House of Commons of England.
He was the eldest son of John Mordaunt, 1st Baron Mordaunt of Turvey by Elizabeth, the daughter and coheiress of Sir Henry Vere of Great Addington, Northamptonshire. He was knighted in 1533 and inherited the title Baron Mordaunt on his father's death in 1562.
He was appointed High Sheriff of Essex and High Sheriff of Hertfordshire for 154041 and Constable of Hertford Castle from 1554. He served as a Privy Councillor (PC) from 1553. He was elected MP for Bedfordshire in 1553, April and November 1554 and 1555.
He died in 1571 and was buried at Turvey. He had married twice: firstly  Ella, the daughter and heiress of John Fitzlewis, with whom he had several sons and 6 daughters and secondly Joan, the daughter of Richard Fermor of Easton Neston, Northamptonshire, and the widow of Robert Wilford of London. He was succeeded by his estranged son Lewis.
summary: Lewis, his estranged son

body: Bill Clifton (July 6, 1916  February 26, 1967) was a Canadian jazz pianist based in New York City for almost three decades. He played with many of the name bands of the swing era and accompanied some of the music industry's most noted vocalists  He is remembered today as an early and important influence on the great jazz pianist Bill Evans.
summary: He is remembered as an early and important influence on Bill Evans.

body: Pinchas Menachem Alter (Hebrew:   , June 9, 1926  March 7, 1996), also known as the Pnei Menachem ( ), after the works he authored, was the seventh rebbe of the Hasidic dynasty of Ger, a position he held from 1992 until his death in 1996. He also served as a member and the president of the Torah Scholars Council and as the chairman of the Agudat Yisrael political party.

body: Schlemm's canal, also known as the canal of Schlemm, and as the scleral venous sinus, is a circular lymphatic-like vessel in the eye. It collects aqueous humor from the anterior chamber and delivers it into the episcleral blood vessels. Canaloplasty may be used to widen it.
summary: Schlemm's canal, also referred to as the canal of Schlemm or the scleral venous sinus, is a circular vessel situated in the eye. It functions similarly to a lymphatic vessel and is an essential component of the ocular structure. Specifically, it is located at the junction between the cornea and the sclera, surrounding the anterior chamber of the eye where aqueous humor, the clear fluid that maintains intraocular pressure and nourishes the eye, is produced.

body: Schlemm's canal, also known as the canal of Schlemm, and as the scleral venous sinus, is a circular lymphatic-like vessel in the eye. It collects aqueous humor from the anterior chamber and delivers it into the episcleral blood vessels. Canaloplasty may be used to widen it.
summary: Schlemm's canal is a small, blind-ending canal located in the eye that connects the sclera (white outer layer of the eye) to the aqueous humor (aqueous fluid that fills the eye). It is located in the area of the eye where the sclera and cornea meet.

Sichan (Persian: , also Romanized as Schn; also known as Schh) is a village in Fasharud Rural District, in the Central District of Birjand County, South Khorasan Province, Iran. At the 2016 census, its population was 72, in 30 families.


== References ==
summary: The population size of Sichan, which is only 72 individuals, reflects a broader demographic trend in rural areas of Iran, where many villages are experiencing depopulation or stagnant growth due to urbanization and migration to cities. Such a small population presents specific challenges for local governance, including limited representation and challenges in sustaining community services. Additionally, resource allocation from the government may be influenced by the small number of residents, potentially leading to reduced funding for infrastructure, education, and healthcare. This trend may necessitate innovative community planning and collaboration among residents to maintain a viable and functional village environment despite the low population.

body:
The 1972 United States Senate election in Maine was held on November 7, 1972. Incumbent Republican U.S. Senator Margaret Chase Smith ran for re-election to a fifth term, but was defeated by Democrat William Hathaway. As of 2024, this was the last time the Democrats won the Class 2 Senate seat from Maine.
As of 2024, this remains one of only two times in history (along with the 1846 election) that a Democrat has been elected to this seat for a full term, and the only such instance since the founding of the Republican Party. Maine was one of fifteen states alongside Alabama, Arkansas, Colorado, Delaware, Georgia, Iowa, Louisiana, Minnesota, Mississippi, Montana, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, South Dakota and West Virginia that were won by Republican President Richard Nixon in 1972 that elected Democrats to the United States Senate.
summary: It is one of only two times a Democrat has been elected to this seat for a full term, and the only instance since the founding of the Republican Party.

Incumbent Republican U.S. Senator Margaret Chase Smith ran for re-election to a fifth term, but was defeated by Democrat William Hathaway. As of 2024, this was the last time the Democrats won the Class 2 Senate seat from Maine.
As of 2024, this remains one of only two times in history (along with the 1846 election) that a Democrat has been elected to this seat for a full term, and the only such instance since the founding of the Republican Party. Maine was one of fifteen states alongside Alabama, Arkansas, Colorado, Delaware, Georgia, Iowa, Louisiana, Minnesota, Mississippi, Montana, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, South Dakota and West Virginia that were won by Republican President Richard Nixon in 1972 that elected Democrats to the United States Senate.
summary: 1972 was the first election after the passage of the Maine Clean Election Act, which established public financing for state elections. This meant that candidates running for office in Maine's Class 2 Senate seat, which includes the two most rural counties in the state, had access to a limited amount of public money for their campaigns. This was a unique context for Democrats in Maine, as they had to compete with candidates from both major parties who were able to raise large amounts of money for their campaigns.

body:
Joe mit (1 February 1922  7 February 2004) was a Slovene poet, translator, editor and journalist.
mit was born in the village of Tlake near Rogatec in eastern Slovenia in 1922. The house in which he was born and spent his childhood is preserved on a new location at the Rogatec Open-Air Museum where it was moved to in 1981 as a typical example of an early 19th-century Sub-Pannonian house. He studied forestry at Vienna between 1942 and 1943 and was drafted into the German Army. During the Invasion of Normandy he was captured and sent to England as a prisoner of war and then to Italy, where he joined the Overseas Brigade of the Yugoslav Liberation Army and returned to Yugoslavia.  After the war he worked as a journalist and studied Comparative literature and Slavic languages and literature at the University of Ljubljana, but was sent to work in Litija and abandoned his studies. He worked as an editor and proof-reader and is also known for his translations, particularly for his translation from the Latin of the poet Catullus. He also wrote prose and poetry for young children. He died in Ljubljana in 2004.
In 1970 he won the Levstik Award for his poetry collection Kako bomo umirali (How We Shall Die).
summary: Comparative literature and Slavic languages and literature

body:
The Jules Verne Viaduct is a viaduct constructed in 1987 that crosses the River Somme near Camon, east of Amiens. It is 943 metres (3,094 ft) long and allows circumvention of the city by roads. It has a deck depth of 3.2 metres (10 ft) and a deck width of 11.45 metres (37.6 ft). It is located at 49 53' 2.28" N, 2 22' 18.42" E. It was designed by Charles Lavigne.


== References ==
summary: Charles Lavigne

body:
Djadochtatheriidae is a family of fossil mammals within the extinct order Multituberculata. Remains are known from the Upper Cretaceous of Central Asia. These animals lived during the Mesozoic, also known as the "age of the dinosaurs". This family is part of the suborder of Cimolodonta. The taxon Djadochtatheriidae was named by Zofia Kielan-Jaworowska and Jrn Hurum in 1997.
Multituberculates are a rather diverse group in terms of locomotion and diet. Forms like Kryptobaatar and Catopsbaatar were hopping, jerboa-like omnivores (and this is probably the ancestral condition for the group, given that Nemegtbaatar also had this lifestyle), while Mangasbaatar was a robust, digging herbivore.
summary: Mangasbaatar

This genus is part of the family Amblycrocodilidae and is known from the Late Eocene to Early Oligocene epochs. Fossil evidence suggests that *Amblycrocuta* had strong limbs and a powerful jaw, which would have been well-suited for digging and foraging for roots and tubers, much like modern-day badgers. However, it is important to note that the exact lifestyle of *Amblycrocuta* is still a subject of research and debate among paleontologists.

body:
The Chess World Cup 2007 served as a qualification tournament for the World Chess Championship 2010. It was held as a 128-player single-elimination tournament, between 24 November and 16 December 2007, in Khanty-Mansiysk, Russia.
In an event attended by most leading players of the world, American Gata Kamsky emerged as the winner. He was unbeaten in the tournament, going into tie-break only once and defeating Spaniard Alexei Shirov, 21, in the four-game final. Two 17-year-old players, Sergey Karjakin and Magnus Carlsen, reached the semifinals.
By winning, Kamsky qualified for the Challenger Match, the final stage in determining the challenger for the World Chess Championship 2010; his participation in that match allowed him direct entry into the Candidates Matches for the World Chess Championship 2012.
The final four also received direct entry into the FIDE Grand Prix 200810, a qualifying stage for the World Chess Championship 2012.
The winner of the Chess World Cup 2005, Levon Aronian, was defeated by Dmitry Jakovenko in the fourth round.
summary: Sergey Karjakin and Magnus Carlsen

summary: The two 17-year-old players who reached the semifinals of the Chess World Cup 2007 were Viswanathan Anand and Boris Gelfand. Viswanathan Anand, who later became the World Chess Champion, and Boris Gelfand, a prominent chess grandmaster, both performed exceptionally well in the tournament.

summary:
Sai Mai, also known as Sai Mai District, is located in the province of Chiang Rai, Thailand. To the north, Sai Mai District is bordered by the following districts and provinces:

1. **Mae Sai District** - This district is part of the Mae Sai District in Chiang Rai Province, which is adjacent to Sai Mai District.
2. **Chiang Saen District** - This district is also part of Chiang Rai Province and is located to the north of Sai Mai District.

These neighboring districts and the province of Chiang Rai share a border with Sai Mai District to the north.

body:
The A Nightmare on Elm Street series, created by Wes Craven, focuses on several characters who survive attacks by Freddy Krueger (Robert Englund), the spirit of a child murderer who gains the ability to stalk and kill people in their dreams (thus killing them in reality) after his death at the hands of a vengeful mob.
The series consists of nine films: A Nightmare on Elm Street (1984), A Nightmare on Elm Street 2: Freddy's Revenge (1985), A Nightmare on Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors (1987), A Nightmare on Elm Street 4: The Dream Master (1988), A Nightmare on Elm Street 5: The Dream Child (1989) and Freddy's Dead: The Final Nightmare (1991), in which Freddy is seemingly killed. A demonic interpretation followed in Wes Craven's New Nightmare (1994), in which Freddy Krueger attempts to break free from the films into the real world. Nearly a decade later, Freddy was involved in a crossover with Jason Voorhees of the Friday the 13th franchise in Freddy vs. Jason (2003). The series was rebooted in 2010 with A Nightmare On Elm Street, a loose remake of the original film with Englund replaced by Jackie Earle Haley and the character changed from child killer to a child molester. The franchise also consists of a television series, a video game, merchandise and literature about Freddy Krueger and his exploits, including crossovers with Jason Voorhees and Ash Williams of the Evil Dead franchise.
In the series Freddy Krueger has the ability to enter people's dreams and control them, taunting and murdering them with his glove (with four blades attached to the fingers, allowing him to slash and stab his victims). Nancy Thompson (Heather Langenkamp) survives his attacks in the original film, and appeared in Dream Warriors. She was replaced by Alice Johnson (Lisa Wilcox) as the protagonist of the fourth and fifth installments, who has special abilities in her dreams which allow her to fight Freddy's machinations. Killed off by his daughter Maggie Burroughs (Lisa Zane) in Freddy's Dead: The Final Nightmare, he returns in subsequent media. In the 2010 franchise reboot starring Jackie Earle Haley as Freddy, the character is changed from a child murderer to a child molester (Craven's intention in the original films). His bladed glove is a gardening tool instead of a handmade item, as in the original film series.
Although some films in the series were critical and financial flops, it is considered one of the most successful media franchises in the US. The series contained the first film appearances of Johnny Depp (A Nightmare on Elm Street) and Patricia Arquette (Dream Warriors), both of whom went on to successful, award-winning careers.
summary: In the 2010 reboot, Freddy Krueger's character was changed from a child murderer to a child molester, which was originally Wes Craven's intention in the original films. Additionally, Freddy's bladed glove was changed from a handmade item to a gardening tool.

The series contained the first film appearances of Johnny Depp (A Nightmare on Elm Street) and Patricia Arquette (Dream Warriors), both of whom went on to successful, award-winning careers.
summary:
In the 2010 reboot of "A Nightmare on Elm Street," directed by Samuel Bayer, Freddy Krueger's character and his iconic glove underwent several changes. Freddy Krueger, portrayed by Jackie Earle Haley, is a more sinister and menacing figure compared to the original character played by Robert Englund. Here are some key changes:

1. **Appearance and Design**: Freddy's appearance in the reboot is more grotesque and terrifying. His face is more heavily scarred, and his eyes are more menacing. The glove itself is redesigned to be more menacing, with a more pronounced and exaggerated appearance.

2. **Glove Design**: The glove in the reboot is more detailed and has a more pronounced, almost skeletal appearance. It has a more prominent, almost claw-like design, which adds to the sense of danger and malevolence.

3. **Personality and Motivation**: Freddy Krueger's motivations in the reboot are more focused on his desire to be remembered and to continue his reign of terror. He is portrayed as a more complex character with a deeper backstory, which adds to his chilling presence.

4. **Abilities and Powers**: Freddy's abilities are more explicitly tied to his dreams. He can manipulate dreams and create nightmares, and his powers are more visually represented in the film. The dream sequences are more intense and visually striking, with Freddy's presence being more tangible and terrifying.

5. **Character Development**: Freddy Krueger's character in the reboot is given more depth, with a backstory that explains his motivations and his connection to the dream world. This adds to the overall horror and suspense of the film.

Overall, the 2010 reboot of "A Nightmare on Elm Street" reimagines Freddy Krueger as a more terrifying and complex antagonist, with significant changes to his appearance, glove design, and character development.

body: "My Heart Takes Over" is the third and final single released from British-Irish girl group The Saturdays' third studio album On Your Radar (2011). The song was written by Ina Wroldsen and Steve Mac and produced by Mac. The single was released on 11 November 2011 in Ireland and on 13 November 2011 in the UK by Polydor Records. The single is their twelfth overall single released to date. It debuted and peaked at number 15 in the UK Singles Chart on 20 November 2011. This became their first single to not sell over 100,000 copies.
summary: My Heart Takes Over

Hystaspes (Old Persian:  Vitspa; Ancient Greek:  Hustsps) was the second son of the Persian king Xerxes I. When his father was assassinated by the vizier Artabanus, Hystaspes' younger brother Artaxerxes I ascended the throne. According to Diodorus of Sicily, Hystaspes was satrap of Bactria at the time of his father's death. This claim of Diodorus conflicts with the version of Ctesias that an Artaban (not to be confused with the murderer of Xerxes I) then led a revolt in Bactria, where he was satrap. It is possible that the true rebel was Hystaspes.
Hystaspes was allegedly assassinated by Artaxerxes I.
summary: Satrap of Bactria

Bell  Mountain, at 11,612 feet (3,539 m) above sea level, is the second highest peak in the Lemhi Range of Idaho. The peak is the highest point in Lemhi County and located 0.2 mi (0.32 km) north of the border with Butte County. The peak is located on the border of Caribou-Targhee National Forest and Salmon-Challis National Forest. It is about 9.5 mi (15.3 km) northwest of Diamond Peak. It is the 37th highest peak in Idaho.
The peak is named after Robert Norman Bell.

Chorley is a town and the administrative centre of the wider Borough of Chorley in Lancashire, England, 8 miles (13 km) north of Wigan, 11 miles (18 km) south west of Blackburn, 11 miles (18 km) north west of Bolton, 12 miles (19 km) south of Preston and 20 miles (32 km) north west of Manchester. The town's wealth came principally from the cotton industry.
In the 1970s, the skyline was dominated by factory chimneys, but most have now been demolished: remnants of the industrial past include Morrisons chimney and other mill buildings, and the streets of terraced houses for mill workers. Chorley is the home of the Chorley cake.
summary: The cotton industry.

The rule was designed to encourage open and frank discussion of international issues by allowing participants to speak freely without revealing their identities or the identities of their organizations or governments. KDRW (88.7 MHz) is a non-commercial FM radio station that is licensed to Santa Barbara, California. The station is owned by Santa Monica College and mostly simulcasts KCRW and its public radio format, a mix of news, talk and specialty music programs, some produced by KCRW and some from NPR. However, KDRW also originates some programming locally from its studios on the campus of Antioch University Santa Barbara.
KDRW has an effective radiated power (ERP) of 12,000 watts, using HD Radio technology.  The transmitter is off Gibraltar Road in Santa Barbara, amid the towers for other local FM and TV stations.

The Petrale sole (Eopsetta jordani) is an edible flatfish of the family Pleuronectidae. It is a demersal fish that lives on sandy bottoms, usually in deep water, down to depths of about 550 metres (1,800 ft). Males can grow to 53 centimetres (21 in) in length, females to 70 centimetres (28 in), and they can weigh up to 3.7 kilograms (8.2 lb). Its native habitat is the Eastern Pacific, stretching from the coast of Baja California in the south to the Aleutian Islands in the Bering Sea in the north.
Petrale sole is an important commercial fish, caught all along the West Coast of the United States and Canada and into the Bering Sea, almost exclusively by trawler.
summary: Petrale sole is considered an important commercial fish and is widely caught along the West Coast of the United States and Canada, extending into the Bering Sea. The primary method used for catching this species is trawling, wherein trawlers are employed to capture these fish due to their demersal nature, allowing efficient fishing on sandy bottoms in deep waters.

summary:
The Petrale sole (Parophrys vetulus) is a species of flatfish that is commercially important due to its relatively high market value and its popularity in various culinary dishes. It is found in the Atlantic Ocean, primarily in the Mediterranean Sea, the Black Sea, and the eastern coast of North America. The fish is known for its delicate, flaky texture and mild flavor, making it a sought-after choice for seafood lovers.

Commercially, the Petrale sole is harvested using a variety of fishing methods, with trawling being the most common. Trawling involves dragging a large net through the water, which captures the fish along with other marine life. This method is efficient and allows for the collection of large quantities of fish, making it suitable for commercial operations. However, it can also result in bycatch, which is the unintentional capture of non-target species, leading to potential ecological concerns.

Another fishing method used for the Petrale sole is longlining, which involves the use of a long line with baited hooks. This method is more selective, as it targets specific species, but it is also more labor-intensive and less efficient than trawling.

In addition to trawling and longlining, the Petrale sole can also be caught using hook-and-line fishing, which is a more sustainable and environmentally friendly method. This technique involves the use of a single hook and line, allowing for the selective capture of the fish without harming other marine life.

Overall, the commercial importance of the Petrale sole lies in its culinary value and its ability to be harvested using various fishing methods. However, it is essential to consider the environmental impact of these methods and to implement sustainable fishing practices to ensure the long-term viability of the species.

body:
Girl Talk were a British girl group, formed by Karen Wright and Leigh Pearce. The girls, aged 12 and 13 respectively, released their debut single, "Can the Rhythm", in 1983 on Park Records. By the next year Pearce had been replaced by Karen's sister, Julie Wright. In March 1984, the duo took part in the Irish National Song Contest; the heat for Eurovision Song Contest, with the song "Problems". Later that year they signed to Innervision Records and released the single "Marvellous Guy" in 1984, produced by Peter Collins, but it failed to chart. Their only hit in the UK was their second Innervision single, a re-recorded "Can the Rhythm", which reached #92 in October 1984. The track was an early production of the hitmaking team Stock Aitken Waterman. "Can the Rhythm" was also released in the United States, where it was released through Geffen Records and reached #26 on the Billboard Hot Dance Club Play chart in 1985.
In 1987, the sisters moved to WEA and released two further singles, "Falling for You" (produced by the Quick) and "I Will Give You Love" (produced by John Rocca), which both failed to chart.
Unlike most of the girl groups of the era, three of their singles were written solely by a group member; in this case, by Karen Wright.
summary: Unlike most girl groups of the era, three of the singles by Girl Talk were written solely by a group member, Karen Wright. This highlights a level of creative contribution that was not common among similar groups at the time, where often, external writers and producers were used for songwriting.

Girl Talk, the project of American musician Todd Rundgren, is known for its unique approach to music production, which significantly differs from the traditional composition process of girl groups of their era. Todd Rundgren, the mastermind behind Girl Talk, is responsible for this change. Here are some key aspects of how Girl Talk's singles differ from those of typical girl groups:

1. **Sampling and Mashups**: Todd Rundgren's Girl Talk is famous for its extensive use of sampling, where he takes snippets from a wide variety of songs across different genres and eras, and combines them into a single track. This approach creates a collage of sounds that is quite distinct from the original compositions of girl groups, which typically consist of original songs written and performed by the group members.

2. **Diverse Influences**: While girl groups often draw from a relatively narrow range of musical influences, Girl Talk's tracks are a melting pot of styles, including rock, pop, hip-hop, electronic, and more. This eclectic mix is a result of Rundgren's extensive music library and his ability to seamlessly blend different genres.

3. **Production Techniques**: Rundgren's production techniques in Girl Talk are highly experimental. He often manipulates the tempo, pitch, and rhythm of the sampled material to create a unique sound. This level of production complexity is not typically found in the music of girl groups, which usually rely on simpler, more straightforward arrangements.

4. **Conceptual Approach**: Girl Talk's singles often have a conceptual theme, with Rundgren creating entire albums that tell a story or explore a particular idea through the use of samples. This contrasts with the more straightforward, often love-themed songs of girl groups.

5. **Collaboration and Remix Culture**: Rundgren's work with Girl Talk has also contributed to the broader culture of remixing and collaboration in music. By taking existing songs and recontextualizing them, he has influenced other artists to explore similar techniques, thereby changing the landscape of music production.

Todd Rundgren's innovative approach to music production with Girl Talk has indeed set him apart from the typical girl group of his era, and his influence can be seen in the way music is created and consumed today.

Derriaghy Cricket Club Football Club, often simply known as Derriaghy CC or Derriaghy Cricket Club, is a Northern Irish intermediate-level football club playing in the Premier Division of the Northern Amateur Football League. The club is based in Derriaghy, County Antrim, was formed in 1982 when the long-established Derriaghy Cricket Club decided to add a football section. Domo de la Feria (originally Auditorio Municipal de Leon) is a 4,463-seat indoor arena located in Leon, Guanajuato.  Built in the mid-1980s, it is used primarily for basketball, and is home to the Abejas de Len basketball team.  It is part of the municipal fairgrounds, and is one of the primary venues of the annual Feria Leon.  It can seat up to 7,000 for concerts. It is also used for circuses, lucha libre, motorsports, boxing, graduations, ice shows and other events.  A 4,500-seat Palenque, dedicated in 2010, is adjacent to the arena.
Among the many acts who have performed at Domo de la Feria have been: Paty Cant, Rocio Durcal, Lupita D'Alessio, Vicente Fernandez, Joan Sebastian, Juan Gabriel, Maribel Guardia, Lucero, Gloria Trevi, Thala, Paulina Rubio, Los Tigres del Norte, Lorena Herrera, Mana, Jenni Rivera, Banda del Recodo, Danna Paola, Aracely Arambula, Pepe Aguilar, WWE Live and many others.

Volleyball matches have also been presented, its main event in this sport was the 2017 World Volleyball League organized by the FIVB, where the semi-finals and final of Group 3.7 were played. This venue has also been the venue for sports such as Futsal, Female American Football, Boxing, Handball, Judo, Karate, Olympic Wrestling, Mixed Martial Arts, Taekwondo and Professional Wrestling with WWE, Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide, Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre, and The Crash Lucha Libre.
The Dome of the Fair has a total of 4,463 seats inside this, which are divided into three zones, the upper area has 1,099 seats, the intermediate area has 1,831 seats and the lower area has 1,533 seats. The surface of the stage is 36m x 22m and its maximum height is 16m. Lighting has 28 lamps of 1000 Watts each.
It hosted all matches for the 2023 FIBA Women's AmeriCup.
It also hosted matches for the 2024 FIBA Under-17 Women's Basketball World Cup including the final phase.
summary: Domo de la Feria has hosted various sports events, including the 2017 World Volleyball League, matches for the 2023 FIBA Women's AmeriCup, and this venue has been used for sports like futsal, female American football, boxing, handball, judo, karate, Olympic wrestling, mixed martial arts, and professional wrestling events from WWE, Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide, Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre, The Crash Lucha Libre.

Ahmed Abd al-Karim al-Saadi aka Abu Mohjen is a Palestinian who became the leader of Osbat al-Ansar in 1991 after founder Sheik Hisham Shreidi was killed by Fatah rivals. Abu Mohjen is believed to have been behind the transformation of Osbat al-Ansar from a Palestinian-centered militant group into an al-Qaeda supported pan-Islamic organization.  
Abu Mohjen has been sentenced to death in absentia by Lebanon; however, his sentence was later reduced to 20 years hard labor. After being sentenced by the Lebanese government Abu Mohjen has remained in hiding. It is assumed that his brother Abu Tarek al-Saadi has assumed control of Osbat al-Ansar while Abu Mohjen remains in hiding either in Iraq or in the Palestinian refugee camp of Ain al-Hilweh.
summary: In Iraq or in the Palestinian refugee camp of Ain al-Hilweh.

"Sleigh Ride" is a light orchestra standard composed by Leroy Anderson. He formed the idea for the piece during a heat wave in July 1946, and finished it in February 1948. Its first performance was by the Boston Pops Orchestra, with Arthur Fiedler conducting, on May 4, 1948. Anderson also made arrangements for wind band and piano.
The original recordings were instrumental versions: it was first recorded in 1949 by Fiedler and the Boston Pops. As a 45 rpm version issued on red vinyl, "Sleigh Ride" was a hit record on RCA Victor Red Seal and has become one of the orchestra's best-known works. The Pops have recorded the piece numerous times, with Fiedler as well as John Williams, their conductor from 1979 to 1995, and Keith Lockhart, their current conductor.
The lyrics, about riding in a sleigh and other wintertime activities, were written by Mitchell Parish in 1950.
The Ronettes recorded a cover of "Sleigh Ride" in 1963 for Phil Spector's A Christmas Gift for You, which was commercially successful in the United States and featured in various media. The song has since been associated with the Christmas and holiday season.
summary: The lyrics for 'Sleigh Ride,' which are about riding in a sleigh and other wintertime activities, were written by Mitchell Parish in 1950.

body:
La Sonnambula (The Sleepwalker) is a ballet by the co-founder and ballet master of New York City Ballet, George Balanchine, made to Vittorio Rieti's music using themes from the operas of Vincenzo Bellini including La Sonnambula, Norma, I Puritani and I Capuleti e i Montecchi (183035).
The ballet premiered as The Night Shadow  with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo on Wednesday, 27 February 1946, at City Center of Music and Drama, New York, with sets and costumes designed by Dorothea Tanning and costumes executed by Karinska. It was first performed by the New York City Ballet on 6 January 1960 at City Center of Music and Drama.  

The ballet tells the story of a Coquette, a Poet, and a beautiful Sleepwalker. The original 1946 program describes the story as follows: Amid the somber walls of a decaying castle a masked ball has just begun.  The host, an eccentric nobleman, receives his guests, among them a poet and a dazzling coquette.  The poet, seduced by her charms, dances with her as the guests gradually leave the scene, then she too leaves.  As the poet turns to follow, he sees a lovely white apparition gliding across the roofs toward him.  It comes nearer and he sees that it is a beautiful somnambulist.  He loses his heart to her at once, unaware that she is married to the host who keeps her locked away from the world.  They dance, and he sees to join her in her realm of dreaming sleep.  But they are seen.  The coquette, flushed with jealousy, steals out to tell the host....All too soon the marvelous sleep-walker drifts away.  The poet would follow her but the guests reenter and their dancing forms a barrier.  Finally, he breaks through and disappears but the host follows too and stabs him.  As he lies unconscious among the terrified guests the white figure of his love appears once more, gently raises him and together they glide away.
The ballet was renamed La Sonnambula in 1961, and has been revived numerous times.
summary: The ballet originally premiered under the name 'The Night Shadow' with sets and costumes designed by Dorothea Tanning, and the costumes executed by Karinska.

Henner's designs for "La Sylphide" helped to create the otherworldly atmosphere that is characteristic of the ballet.

body: Young Modern is the fifth and final studio album by Australian alternative rock band Silverchair, released in Australia on 31 March 2007 and in the United States on  24 July 2007 and co-produced by Daniel Johns and Nick Launay. The title comes from a nickname given to Daniel Johns by composer Van Dyke Parks. The tracks "Straight Lines", "Reflections of a Sound", "If You Keep Losing Sleep" and "Mind Reader" were released as singles. Young Modern entered the Australian albums chart at No. 1 on 15 April 2007, their fifth consecutive album to do this, making Silverchair the first band to accomplish this feat in Australia. The album was certified Triple Platinum by the ARIA, peaked at No. 70 on the US Billboard 200 chart and opened at No. 8 on the New Zealand albums chart. Young Modern won six ARIA Awards in 2007, including Best Group, Best Rock Album, Single of the Year (for "Straight Lines") and Album of the Year. At the J Awards of 2007, the album was nominated for Australian Album of the Year.
summary: Six ARIA Awards; Best Group, Best Rock Album, Single of the Year.

body: Federal elections were held in all the 38 states of the German Confederation on 1 May 1848 to elect members of a new National Assembly known as the Frankfurt Parliament. The ballot was not secret, and elected 585 members, mostly from the middle class.
summary:
The Frankfurt Parliament, convened in 1848, was a significant event in German history as it was the first freely elected parliament for all of Germany. The elections for the Frankfurt Parliament were notable for several reasons:


1. **Universal Suffrage**: For the first time, a large portion of the German population was allowed to vote. This was a significant step towards democratic representation, although the right to vote was still limited to men, and the electorate was restricted to those who met certain property and tax-paying requirements.


2. **National Unity**: The election of the Frankfurt Parliament was an attempt to unify the various German states under a single national government. The parliament aimed to create a constitution for a unified Germany, which was a revolutionary idea at the time.


3. **Political Participation**: The elections were a demonstration of political participation by a broad segment of the population, including intellectuals, students, and members of the middle class, who were eager for political reform and national unity.


4. **Challenges and Limitations**: Despite the significance of the elections, the parliament faced numerous challenges, including a lack of support from the German princes, who were reluctant to give up their sovereignty. The parliament's inability to enforce its decisions and the eventual dissolution of the parliament in 1849 highlighted the limitations of the electoral process and the difficulties in achieving national unity.


The Frankfurt Parliament's elections were a landmark in the history of German democracy, setting the stage for future political developments, even though the immediate outcomes were not as successful as the participants had hoped.

body:
John Trim (25 January 1915  12 November 1960) was a West Indian cricketer who played in four Tests from 1948 to 1952. A barrel-chested right-arm fast-medium bowler and right-handed lower-order batsman from Berbice, British Guiana, Trim's brief international career yielded 18 wickets at one of the lowest bowling averages of any completed career  16.16 runs per wicket. In his first class career from 1944 to 1953 he played 34 matches, mostly for British Guiana, taking 96 wickets and making a solitary half-century with the bat.
Trim's Test debut came during the 194748 tour of the West Indies by Gubby Allen's England team. Trim took two wickets for an economical six runs in his first outing, with a further wicket in England's second innings. It was Trim's only match of the series, but he would tour India in January 1949, taking 4/48 and 3/28 in Chennai and 3/69 in Mumbai. He was then selected for the West Indian tour of Australia 195152 and took his career-best figures: a maiden five wicket haul of 5/35 at the Melbourne Cricket Ground. His omission from the 1950 touring party to England created an almighty row and almost led to the British Guiana Cricket Association boycotting the tour.
Trim was the first Berbician to play Test cricket. He continued to play cricket in the Caribbean until 1953. He died in New Amsterdam, Berbice.
summary: John Trim played in four Test matches between 1948 and 1952.

body: The biopsychiatry controversy is a dispute over which viewpoint should predominate and form a basis of psychiatric theory and practice. The debate is a criticism of a claimed strict biological view of psychiatric thinking. Its critics include disparate groups such as the antipsychiatry movement and some academics.
summary: The antipsychiatry movement and some academics.

body: The biopsychiatry controversy is a dispute over which viewpoint should predominate and form a basis of psychiatric theory and practice. The debate is a criticism of a claimed strict biological view of psychiatric thinking. Its critics include disparate groups such as the antipsychiatry movement and some academics.
summary:
The strict biological view of psychiatric thinking, which emphasizes the role of genetics, neurochemistry, and brain structure in mental disorders, has faced criticism from various quarters. Critics argue that this perspective can be reductionist, overlooking the complex interplay of environmental, psychological, and social factors that contribute to mental health. Some of the critics include:

1. **Psychologists and Psychiatrists**: Some mental health professionals argue that the biopsychosocial model, which considers biological, psychological, and social factors, provides a more comprehensive understanding of mental health and illness.

2. **Sociologists and Anthropologists**: These scholars often emphasize the importance of cultural, social, and environmental factors in shaping mental health. They argue that mental disorders cannot be fully understood without considering the broader social context.

3. **Philosophers**: Some philosophers critique the reductionist approach of the strict biological view, arguing that it fails to account for the subjective experiences and meanings that individuals attach to their mental states.

4. **Humanists and Existentialists**: These thinkers often emphasize the importance of personal agency, meaning, and the human experience. They argue that mental health cannot be fully understood through a purely biological lens.

5. **Social Justice Advocates**: Critics from this group argue that the strict biological view can lead to stigmatization and discrimination, particularly for marginalized groups. They emphasize the need to consider social determinants of health, such as poverty, discrimination, and access to care.

6. **Cultural Critics**: Some critics argue that the strict biological view can be ethnocentric, failing to account for cultural variations in the understanding and expression of mental health.

These critics advocate for a more holistic approach to understanding and treating mental health, one that integrates biological, psychological, and social perspectives.

The 201718 Swiss Super League (referred to as the Raiffeisen Super League for sponsoring reasons) was the 121st season of top-tier competitive football in Switzerland and the 15th under its current name and format. Basel were the defending champions. Young Boys won the title on 28 April 2018 after a 21 win against Luzern, with four games to spare. It was their first league title in 32 years, having last won the league in the 19851986 season, and their 12th league title overall. They also ended Basel's run of eight consecutive titles. 
A total of 10 teams competed in the league: the 9 best teams from the 201617 season and the 201617 Swiss Challenge League champion Zrich. The season started on the weekend of 2223 July 2017 and ended on 19 May 2018 with a break between 17 December 2017 and 2 February 2018.
This season saw the introduction of changes in the way Swiss clubs may qualify for European competition; per new UEFA rules, the champions of the Swiss Super League now qualifies for the Champions League play-off round (previously directly to the Champions League group stage) and the runners-up now qualifies for the Champions League second qualifying round (previously to the third qualifying round). Qualification to Europa League spots for the third- and fourth-placed team remain unchanged.
summary: Basel

RealityCapture (RC) is a photogrammetry software for creating 3D models out of unordered photographs (terrestrial and/or aerial) or laser scans without seams. The most common fields of its current use are cultural heritage (art, archaeology, and architecture), full body scanning, gaming, surveying, mapping, visual effects (VFX) and virtual reality (VR) in general.
It features include image registration (alignment), automatic calibration, calculating a polygon mesh, colouring, texturing, parallel projections, georeferencing, DSM, coordinate system conversion, simplification, scaling, filtration, smoothing, measurement, inspection, and various exports and imports. The program can be run under the command line. There is also a software developer kit available.
RealityCapture is able to mix camera images and laser scans. It is designed to make low demands on hardware. It works linearly, which means if its inputs are doubled, the processing time will be doubled as well. The software is currently available only in English language.
summary: The processing time doubles if the inputs are doubled.

body:
RealityCapture (RC) is a photogrammetry software for creating 3D models out of unordered photographs (terrestrial and/or aerial) or laser scans without seams. The most common fields of its current use are cultural heritage (art, archaeology, and architecture), full body scanning, gaming, surveying, mapping, visual effects (VFX) and virtual reality (VR) in general.
It features include image registration (alignment), automatic calibration, calculating a polygon mesh, colouring, texturing, parallel projections, georeferencing, DSM, coordinate system conversion, simplification, scaling, filtration, smoothing, measurement, inspection, and various exports and imports. The program can be run under the command line. There is also a software developer kit available.
RealityCapture is able to mix camera images and laser scans. It is designed to make low demands on hardware. It works linearly, which means if its inputs are doubled, the processing time will be doubled as well. The software is currently available only in English language.
summary:
RealityCapture, a photogrammetry software, processes 3D models from photographs. As the input size increases, such as more images, higher resolution images, or larger scenes, the processing time generally increases. This is because the software has to handle more data, which requires more computational resources and time to process.

The increase in processing time with larger input sizes can be attributed to several factors:

1. **Image Processing**: More images mean more data to process, which can increase the time required for aligning and matching the images.

2. **Feature Extraction**: With more images, the software has to extract and process more features, which can be computationally intensive.

3. **Mesh Generation**: The complexity of the scene increases with the number of images, leading to a more complex mesh that takes longer to generate.

4. **Optimization**: Larger scenes may require more optimization steps to ensure the final model is accurate and efficient, which can add to the processing time.

5. **Hardware Limitations**: The processing power of the computer running RealityCapture will also play a significant role. More powerful hardware can handle larger inputs more efficiently, but there are practical limits to what can be achieved with consumer-grade hardware.

To manage increased input sizes, users can:

- Use a more powerful computer with a faster processor, more RAM, and a better graphics card.
- Optimize the input by reducing the resolution of images or the number of images if possible.
- Break down the scene into smaller, more manageable parts and process them separately before combining them into a single model.
- Utilize cloud processing services that can handle larger datasets and provide more computational power.

It's important to note that while RealityCapture is designed to handle large datasets, there will always be a trade-off between input size and processing time. Users should plan their projects accordingly and consider the limitations of their hardware when working with large-scale photogrammetry projects.

body:
Mikhail Aleksandrovich Okhitovich (Russian:   ) (18961937) was a Soviet sociologist, town planner and Constructivist architectural theorist, most famous for his 'Disurbanist' proposals of 192930.
Okhitovich, born in Saint Petersburg, joined the Bolshevik Party in 1917 and served in the Red Army from then until 1925. He became a supporter of the Left Opposition of Leon Trotsky, leading to his expulsion in 1928. He was readmitted to the Party in 1930, at which time his theories were garnering a great deal of attention. Disurbanism, which he propounded mainly via the OSA Group's journal SA, is a theory resembling Frank Lloyd Wright's Broadacre City: an abandonment of the metropolis in favour of a diffuse, partly agricultural but technologically advanced network. His proposals were, along with other OSA members, the basis of the rejected Magnitogorsk plan of 1930 and a 'Green City' competition of the same year. Le Corbusier's riposte to Okhitovich's proposals would become the Ville Radieuse.
In 1933 Okhitovich was reprimanded by the Communist Party and in 1935, a speech of his in which he defended Constructivism and attacked the Stalinist 'cult of hierarchy' and nationalism caused consternation. A campaign led by Karo Alabyan and Arkady Mordvinov led to his arrest the same year. He was sent to the Gulag, where he died 1937.
summary: His proposals, along with those of other OSA members, were the basis of the rejected Magnitogorsk plan of 1930.

Mikhail Okhitovich was a prominent Soviet architect and urban planner who played a significant role in the development of Magnitogorsk, a major industrial city in the Ural region of Russia. The connection between Okhitovich and the 1930 Magnitogorsk plan is rooted in his involvement in the city's planning and construction during the early Soviet period.

In the 1930s, Magnitogorsk was envisioned as a massive industrial complex, and its development was part of the broader Soviet strategy to rapidly industrialize the country. Okhitovich, along with other architects and planners, was tasked with designing the layout and infrastructure of the city. His work included the planning of industrial buildings, residential areas, and public spaces, as well as the overall urban design that would support the city's industrial activities.

The Magnitogorsk plan of 1930, which laid out the initial vision for the city's development, was heavily influenced by the principles of Soviet urban planning and the need to create a self-sufficient industrial hub. Okhitovich's contributions to this plan were crucial in shaping the early stages of Magnitogorsk's growth and establishing its role as a key center of Soviet industry.

In summary, Mikhail Okhitovich's connection to the 1930 Magnitogorsk plan lies in his role as an architect and urban planner who helped design and implement the city's early development, contributing to its transformation into a major industrial metropolis.

This is a list of foreign players in the Ligue 1, which commenced play in 1932. The following players must meet both of the following two criteria:

Have played at least one Ligue 1 game. Players who were signed by Ligue 1 clubs, but only played in lower league, cup and/or European games, or did not play in any competitive games at all, are not included.
Are considered foreign, i.e., outside France and its dependencies (Guadeloupe, Martinique, Reunion Island or French Polynesia), determined by the following:
A player is considered foreign if he is not eligible to play for the national teams of France.
More specifically,

If a player has been capped on international level, the national team is used; if he has been capped by more than one country, the highest level (or the most recent) team is used. These include French players with dual citizenship. Players who played for France but came as foreign players (such as Miguel ngel Lauri) are also listed.
If a player has not been capped on international level, his country of birth is used, except those who were born abroad from French parents or moved to France at a young age, and those who clearly indicated to have switched his nationality to another nation.
Clubs listed are those that the player has played at least one Ligue 1 game for.
Seasons listed are those that the player has played at least one Ligue 1 game in. Note that seasons, not calendar years, are used. For example, "1992-95" indicates that the player has played in every season from 199293 to 199495, but not necessarily every calendar year from 1992 to 1995.
In bold:  players still active in Ligue 1 and their respective teams in current season.
summary: The player must have played at least one Ligue 1 game.

body: Gaius Verres (c. 114  43 BC) was a Roman magistrate, notorious for his misgovernment of Sicily. His extortion of local farmers and plundering of temples led to his prosecution by Cicero, whose accusations were so devastating that his defence advocate could only recommend that Verres should leave the country. Cicero's prosecution speeches were later published as the Verrines.
summary: As a consequence of his actions in Sicily, which included extorting local farmers and plundering temples, Gaius Verres faced prosecution by Cicero. The accusations were so powerful that his defence advocate had no choice but to recommend that Verres leave the country. Cicero's prosecution was compelling enough to lead to the publication of the Verrines.

body: Gaius Verres (c. 114  43 BC) was a Roman magistrate, notorious for his misgovernment of Sicily. His extortion of local farmers and plundering of temples led to his prosecution by Cicero, whose accusations were so devastating that his defence advocate could only recommend that Verres should leave the country. Cicero's prosecution speeches were later published as the Verrines.
summary:
Gaius Verres was a Roman governor of Sicily from 73 to 71 BC, and his tenure is infamous for corruption and abuse of power. The consequences of his actions were significant and had a lasting impact on Roman politics and society:

1. **Public Outcry and Political Repercussions**: Verres' actions led to widespread outrage among the Sicilian population and the Roman Senate. His abuse of power, embezzlement, and exploitation of Sicilian resources were seen as egregious violations of Roman law and ethics.

2. **The Case of Cicero**: The most famous consequence of Verres' actions was the trial of Marcus Tullius Cicero, who was a young lawyer at the time. Cicero, representing a group of Sicilians, brought a case against Verres, accusing him of various crimes, including extortion, embezzlement, and abuse of power. The trial, known as the "Pro Verrem," was a landmark event in Roman legal history and showcased Cicero's oratorical skills.

3. **Cicero's Orations**: Cicero's speeches against Verres, particularly the "Pro Milone" and "Pro Cluentio," were highly influential and helped to establish Cicero's reputation as a great orator and statesman. These speeches also contributed to the decline of Verres' political career.

4. **Verres' Downfall**: As a result of the trial and the public outcry, Verres was forced to flee Rome to avoid arrest. He eventually went into exile in Asia Minor, where he lived out the rest of his life in relative obscurity.

5. **Impact on Roman Governance**: The case against Verres highlighted the need for greater oversight and accountability in the administration of Roman provinces. It also demonstrated the power of the Roman legal system and the potential for individuals to challenge corruption and abuse of power.

6. **Cicero's Political Career**: The trial and Cicero's subsequent actions against Verres helped to launch Cicero's political career. He later became a consul in 63 BC and played a key role in the political events leading up to the fall of the Roman Republic.

In summary, the consequences of Gaius Verres' actions in Sicily were profound, leading to his downfall, the rise of Cicero, and a greater awareness of the need for accountability in Roman governance.

body: Suo Chen (died c.18 December 316), courtesy name Juxiu, was a military general of the Western Jin dynasty. He was a prominent member of the group at Anding to restore Jin authority in the north following the Disaster of Yongjia in July 311 and was Emperor Min's most powerful official alongside Qu Yun.  Throughout Emperor Min's reign, he constantly clashed with the Han-Zhao general Liu Yao but was ultimately unable to halt Han's advances into Chang'an. After the fall of Chang'an in 316, Suo was executed for disloyalty, after he had used Emperor Min's surrender as a means to secure a high position for himself in the Han regime. His name can be rendered as Suo Lin.
summary: He was executed for disloyalty after using Emperor Min's surrender to secure a high position for himself in the Han regime.

Suo Chen was a prominent military leader and politician who played a significant role in the events leading up to the fall of Chang'an, the capital of the Eastern Jin Dynasty.

In 316, the Eastern Jin Dynasty faced a severe crisis as the capital, Chang'an, was besieged by the forces of the warlord Yuan Shao. Suo Chen, who was a key figure in the Jin court, was accused of treason and collusion with Yuan Shao. His involvement in the political machinations and his failure to effectively defend the capital led to his downfall.

Suo Chen's execution was part of the broader purge of officials and military leaders who were blamed for the dynasty's inability to maintain control over its territories and protect the capital. His death marked a significant moment in the decline of the Eastern Jin Dynasty, as it further weakened the central authority and contributed to the eventual fragmentation of the Jin state.

body: A Defeated People is a 1946 British documentary short film made by the Crown Film Unit, directed by Humphrey Jennings and narrated by William Hartnell. The film depicts the shattered state of Germany, both physically and as a society, in the immediate aftermath of World War II. The narration explains what is being done  and what needs to be done  both by the occupying Allied forces and the German people themselves to build a better Germany from the ruins.
summary: The shattered state of Germany, both physically and as a society.

body: A Defeated People is a 1946 British documentary short film made by the Crown Film Unit, directed by Humphrey Jennings and narrated by William Hartnell. The film depicts the shattered state of Germany, both physically and as a society, in the immediate aftermath of World War II. summary:
"A Defeated People" (German: "Die verlorene Generation") is a 1951 West German film directed by Wolfgang Staudte. The film is a poignant and powerful portrayal of the lives of German civilians in the aftermath of World War II, particularly focusing on the experiences of those who were directly affected by the war and its consequences.

The film depicts the struggles and hardships faced by the German population during the immediate post-war period. It highlights the widespread suffering, including the loss of loved ones, the destruction of homes and cities, and the pervasive sense of guilt and shame that many Germans felt. The narrative follows a group of young people who are trying to rebuild their lives in a devastated country, dealing with the trauma of the war, the loss of their families, and the challenges of living in a society that is still grappling with the aftermath of the Nazi regime.

The film is notable for its realistic and unflinching portrayal of the emotional and psychological impact of the war on ordinary people. It explores themes of grief, guilt, and the search for meaning in a world that has been irrevocably changed. "A Defeated People" is considered a significant work in German cinema and is often cited as an important contribution to the genre of post-war German films, which sought to come to terms with the country's recent past.

Frank Morris (May 20, 1923  April 10, 2009) was a professional Canadian football offensive lineman and defensive lineman who played 14 seasons in the Canadian professional leagues for the Toronto Argonauts and the Edmonton Eskimos. He was a part of six Grey Cup championship teams (three with the Argonauts and three with the Eskimos) as a player and seven Grey Cup teams as a member of management and player personnel. He was inducted into the Canadian Football Hall of Fame in 1983.
Morris died on April 10, 2009, in Edmonton following a lengthy illness.

The 202122 Q Tour was a series of snooker tournaments that took place during the 202122 snooker season. The Q Tour is the second-tier tour, run by the World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association, for players not on the main World Snooker Tour. Initially announced in July 2020, the tour was delayed by a year and started in late 2021.
A series of four events were organised with the leading money-winner gaining a place on the main tour for the 202223 snooker season. Si Jiahui led the list but had already got a place on tour, so Sean OSullivan, who finished second, got the place. The 16 highest-ranked players who had not already got a place on the main tour for the 202223 season, gained entry to a further event, the WPBSA Q Tour Playoff, the winner of which also got a place. Julien Leclercq won this event, beating Alex Clenshaw 52 in the final.

body:
Umadevi (; c. 1150  1218) was one of the wives of King Veera Ballala II and a Mysore general during the Chalukya campaigns.
Born around 1150, Umadevi became one of the consort of Bellala II at age twenty-two. She commanded Mysore armies against the rival Chalukyas on at least two occasions, allowing Bellala to concentrate on administrative matters. Significantly contributing to the Hoysalas conquest of the Chalkyua at Kalyani (near present-day Bidar) in 1190, she eventually committed suicide, according to the Indian tradition of sati, following her husband's death in 1218.


== References ==
summary: King Veera Ballala II

The Diapontian Islands or Diapontia Islands (Greek:  , romanized: Diapntia Nisi, also known as Othonoi Islands (Greek:  , romanized: Nsoi Othono) are a Greek island group in the Ionian Sea. They are located northwest of Corfu. The main and the only inhabited islands of the archipelago are Othoni, Ereikoussa and Mathraki. The complex includes also the islets and rocks of Diakopo, Diaplo, Karavi, Kastrino, Leipso, Ostrako, Plaka, Plateia and Tracheia.
The largest island is Othoni, with an area of 10.8 km2 and it's the most populated with 457 inhabitants according to the 2021 census. The islands are the westernmost point in Greece and administratively belong to Corfu regional unit. The islands today are a tranquil place for holidays.

Classics is a compilation album by classical crossover soprano Sarah Brightman. It collects previously released material, such as "Pie Jesu", from Andrew Lloyd Webber's Requiem; "Figlio Perduto", "Lascia ch'io pianga" and "La Luna" from Brightman's previous studio albums, and new recordings of some her classical vocal performances, including "Ave Maria", "Dans La Nuit", "Alhambra" and a solo version of the 1997' hit "Time to Say Goodbye".
Entertainment Weekly, although calling Brightman a "stronger song stylist than a singer", gave the album a grade of B. Classics was re-released in Europe in 2006, with the same cover art but a different track listing, as Classics: The Best of Sarah Brightman.
summary: Compilation album

West Side School District (or West Side Public Schools) is a public school district based in Greers Ferry, Arkansas, United States. It provides early childhood, elementary and secondary education for more than 500 prekindergarten through grade 12 students at its two facilities in Cleburne County. The district is accredited by the Arkansas Department of Education (ADE).
The district encompasses more than 147.81 square miles (382.8 km2) of land that includes all or portions of Cleburne County and Van Buren County communities, including: Greers Ferry, Higden, and the Cleburne County portion of Fairfield Bay. It also includes Prim and Edgemont.
In 2012, the high school was nationally recognized as a bronze medalist in the Best High Schools Report 2012 developed by U.S. News & World Report.

The 1999 ANZ Tasmanian International was a women's tennis tournament played on outdoor hard courts at the Hobart International Tennis Centre in Hobart in Australia that was part of Tier IVb of the 1999 WTA Tour. It was the sixth edition of the tournament and was held from 11 through 16 January 1999.
Heading into the tournament, Swiss player Patty Schnyder was the defending champion but she didn't defend her singles title due to her playing in Sydney in that same week. In the singles final, Fifth-seeded Chanda Rubin won the title in straight sets over unseeded Italian player, Rita Grande and earned $16,000 first-prize money.
summary: Chanda Rubin

body: Haplogroup E-P147 is a human Y-chromosome DNA haplogroup. Haplogroup E-P147, along with the less common haplogroup E-M75, is one of the two main branches of the older haplogroup E-M96. The E-P147 clade is commonly observed throughout Africa and is divided into two subclades: the less common, haplogroup E-M132, and the more common, haplogroup E-P177.
summary: Haplogroup E-P147 and haplogroup E-M75.

body: Haplogroup E-P147 is a human Y-chromosome DNA haplogroup. Haplogroup E-P147, along with the less common haplogroup E-M75, is one of the two main branches of the older haplogroup E-M96. The E-P147 clade is commonly observed throughout Africa and is divided into two subclades: the less common, haplogroup E-M132, and the more common, haplogroup E-P177.
summary:
Haplogroup E-M96 is a major human Y-chromosome DNA haplogroup that is part of the larger haplogroup E. The two main branches of haplogroup E-M96 are:

1. E-M215 (also known as E1b1b1a1)
2. E-M35 (also known as E1b1b1b)

These branches represent the primary subclades of haplogroup E-M96, which have been identified through genetic studies and are associated with different populations and regions around the world. E-M215 is particularly significant as it is the most common subclade and is found in large populations in West Africa, the Horn of Africa, and parts of the Middle East. E-M35, on the other hand, is less common and has a more limited geographic distribution.

The twentieth series of the British reality television programme The Only Way Is Essex was confirmed on 3 June 2015 when it was announced that it had renewed for at least a further six series, taking it up to 21 series. The series launched on 5 March with the cast going to Tenerife, and concluded on 3 May 2017 after eighteen episodes, making this the longest series to date. Ahead of the series it was announced that James Argent had taken a break from the series having only appeared in the first half of the previous series. It was also announced that Mario Falcone, Jamie Reed and Charlie King would all be returning to the series. Lauren Pope also made a return to the series during the final episode, and Fran Parman also made a brief return during this episode.
This was the first series to include new cast members Amber Turner, Myles Barnett, Yazmin Oukhellou, Jack Rigden, Jordan Brook and Jade Lewis. This was the final series to include cast members Ben Shenel and Ercan Ramadan, as well as Kate Wright who announced her departure ahead of the final episode. This series focused on the end of the line for the relationship between Megan and Pete, a divide forming following the fallout between Chloe S and Megan, as well as Gemma focusing her attention on having a baby. It also includes Amber D and Chris.
